content.raw: Note that this syntax is being proposed on pull requests [ign-gui #163](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gui/pull-requests/163) and [ign-gui #164](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gui/pull-requests/164) and hasn't been merged yet. I think this is why your screenshots display the world control and status plugins as a blue box on the top left corner.
content.html: Note that this syntax is being proposed on pull requests ign-gui #163 and ign-gui #164 and hasn't been merged yet. I think this is why your screenshots display the world control and status plugins as a blue box on the top left corner.

pullrequest.title: Ensure correct transform for canonical link

content.raw:
>  I would suggest that we reconsider defining these poses as relative to the model transform

There's a lot of work still to be done on the poses. Right now we're propagating the SDF spec, where the pose is always wrt to the parent entity. There have been talks of supporting arbitrary frames of reference. A couple of considerations:

* It probably makes sense to use a single convention within the ECS
* I think we'll need a central tool which helps systems easily transform from one frame to another
content.html:
I would suggest that we reconsider defining these poses as relative to the model transform

There's a lot of work still to be done on the poses. Right now we're propagating the SDF spec, where the pose is always wrt to the parent entity. There have been talks of supporting arbitrary frames of reference. A couple of considerations:

  • It probably makes sense to use a single convention within the ECS
  • I think we'll need a central tool which helps systems easily transform from one frame to another

pullrequest.title: Ensure correct transform for canonical link

content.raw:
I would urge us to represent all ECS kinematic data in the world frame, for a multitude of reasons:

1. It’s almost always the most useful frame of reference for systems \(e.g. physics systems and rendering systems\)
2. It eliminates huge amounts of complexity, pain points, and potential confusion over how we’re representing data
3. It allows one system \(physics\) to be responsible for computing forward kinematics, and then all other systems can benefit from that one-time computation
4. When transforming between reference frames, you almost always convert to the world frame first, so if we have a system that converts between reference frames, then it would want to consume world frame data anyhow

If there’s an ongoing discussion for this topic, I could post these points there instead.
content.html:
I would urge us to represent all ECS kinematic data in the world frame, for a multitude of reasons:

  1. It’s almost always the most useful frame of reference for systems (e.g. physics systems and rendering systems)
  2. It eliminates huge amounts of complexity, pain points, and potential confusion over how we’re representing data
  3. It allows one system (physics) to be responsible for computing forward kinematics, and then all other systems can benefit from that one-time computation
  4. When transforming between reference frames, you almost always convert to the world frame first, so if we have a system that converts between reference frames, then it would want to consume world frame data anyhow

If there’s an ongoing discussion for this topic, I could post these points there instead.

content.raw:
I think we could start an issue on this repo to discuss this.

I'm fine with any convention, as long as it is the same for all frames. I'm not sure about the world frame being "almost always the most useful frame of reference for systems" though, lots of rendering frameworks position nodes relative to parent nodes.
content.html:
I think we could start an issue on this repo to discuss this.

I'm fine with any convention, as long as it is the same for all frames. I'm not sure about the world frame being "almost always the most useful frame of reference for systems" though, lots of rendering frameworks position nodes relative to parent nodes.
